If your forms are unstable, you're an idiot.
You don't make money with bleeding edge technology. You make money when people put credit card numbers into a form.
That cost the company money. All because they got tricky with forms. Forms should be the most stable thing on your site.
Last night, I tried to make a purchase and because someone got funky with their forms I'm now on the phone trying to complete the same order
Browser vendors, evangelist types and workaday developers all treat forms like an afterthought.
I should have had a chapter about forms in The Uncertain Web. I talk about them, but people have a weird relationship with forms.
@highvoltag3 For sure. It's a nightmare.

Of course, the new browser wars aren't served by delivering new form elements. Form fields don't generate music video Chrome Experiments
To that end, if browse vendors really want to push the web forward, give me better form elements and less WebGL
I'm still mostly solving the problem of capturing input and getting text and numbers onto to the page in a structured way
To be perfectly honest, I could solve the problems I'm solving today for real-life clients with tools that we had ten years ago.
I will add that, in my day-to-day, slinging code for multiple clients, I don't see native features/functionality as a big hole in my tools
I agree 100% with @ppk. The "native" obsession that some people have is misplaced. The web is the web. Let's make the web itself great.

@patrick_h_lauke @nytimes The funniest (?) part is that it's twice wrong. Chrome is actually running on an external (non-touch) monitor
@patrick_h_lauke Feel free!
@patrick_h_lauke @nytimes I feel like buying these companies a touchscreen laptop. Just test! Once! These devices exist in the millions
Visit the @nytimes in IE (pointer events, no "touch") and amazingly you can select text again!
Visit @nytimes with a touchscreen laptop in Chrome and... you're no longer able to select text. You can navigate between articles real good!
It looks like the @nytimes is the latest big organization to break interactions by doing touch as a binary.
Is been a while since I've been on that end of things. I'm having uncomfortable flashbacks

We should ensure that even in the best circumstances we focus our attention on serving our user's needs and not our own vanity.
We should ensure that even in the worst circumstances something useful is there for the user.
We've got to strive to make that the default for the way that we build for the web.
The power of the web is that it's universal. There's no app store. Everything is available to everyone, or at least it should be.

"we should focus on the web’s strengths: simplicity, URLs and reach" 
Stop pushing the web forward http://t.co/ylvnFFkAba
I would bet, that for many mobile apps, page to page transitions rendered on the server would be actually faster and "feel" faster than Ajax
If a site take dozens of seconds to load on mobile the perceived performance of smooth interactions is kind of meaningless, right?
I wonder if one of the original selling points of Ajax is now dead and buried under the weight of 1MB JavaScript payloads
Has anyone ever proposed "excel" like extensions to the <table> element? That seems like an area that browsers should handle.

I'm in Mountain View for lunch.  That's the closest I'll get to tech all week
@highvoltag3 guilty as charged
Setting a good hardware/fast connection barrier to entry basically punches the web in the face. Go build native apps.
People will use all kinds of things to get on the web. THAT'S THE BEST PART OF THE WEB. Finding ways to exclude people is dumb.

I know what you're rationalizing: "no one is going to use a seven year old laptop"

You're wrong.
I want to go to everyone who writes about these baroque architectures like there's no issue with them and hand them a 7 year old laptop
In the rush for 60fps bullshit battles with native we toss the strength of the web (broad compatibility/availability) out the window
We're all so ready to throw away the historical strengths of the web to pander to some small subset on fancy devices and with fast bandwidth

Lies we tell ourselves:
"No one surfs the web without JavaScript"
"Everyone has good hardware now"
"Bandwidth is uniformly good'
We have lost our collective minds. We make architectural choices that abuse our users and then rationalize the problems away.
It's hip though, so people do it. Use Backbone to render static HTML? That's cool, right? 1MB of JS to render 100KB of data. Makes sense!
The obsession with parsing data and rendering full-page HTML in the browser is madness to me. It's intentionally choosing the slow path
The web at its best chooses robust, fast and the stable. Throwing away server rendered HTML is the opposite of that.

Choose the fast thing.
“Is this as fast as sending down the right HTML (and then co-opting it and taking over)? No.”
